title: Game client anti-cheat changes going live
body:
**TL;DR:** Anti-cheat improvements will soon be live. If you run into issues loading League, try temporarily disabling third-party software and reply to the thread below to let us know what did or didn’t work.

Hey everyone,

This week we’re rolling out anti-cheat changes to the League of Legends game client in North America, with other regions scheduled to follow shortly. These changes were created to help protect players from cheaters, and we’ve worked hard to help provide a safer and more competitive playing experience for everyone. 

We’ve collaborated with software vendors and content creators to ensure compatibility with as many products as possible, but unfortunately, our update may still impact some legitimate third-party software. 

There are a lot of legitimate applications out there that we know you love, and we can’t test them all. We’ll need your help to identify the software that’s incompatible.** If you encounter a critical error message during the game**, try temporarily uninstalling or disabling the following software, and then comment below with what you disabled and whether it worked.


    - Security software (anti-virus and anti-malware products)
    - In-game overlay software (Steam, Discord, TeamSpeak, Overwolf, ASUS Sonic Radar, etc)
    - Streaming software (XSplit, OBS, Raptr, etc)
    - Video capture software (Fraps, ShadowPlay, etc)


Our mission in creating this software is to keep the game fair for players everywhere. We know how frustrating it is when new features work in unexpected ways, so please comment below so we can look into any issues you’re facing and work toward resolving them as soon as possible. 

See you on the Rift!

replies.body: Will this affect people playing on Linux using wine?

We've not specifically tested for compatibility with Wine or other Windows emulation or virtualization software. Because of the complex nature of our protection and the many variations of software out there, we can't change our solution to be compatible with all of them. However, we are open to working with any software vendor that wants to make their software compatible.

I tried to get y'all to do this in the past by sending in a support ticket but I'm hoping sending this to someone more involved will help. Wine actually supports a system call to check for it for metrics. 

> There is nothing wrong with detecting Wine for survey purposes. Many developers are surprised to learn that a substantial portion of their userbase has been running their program via Wine; sometimes developers aren't even aware that this is possible. If you still really want to detect Wine, check whether ntdll exports the function wine_get_version. (See http://www.winehq.org/pipermail/wine-devel/2008-September/069387.html )

the wine dev team has always worked to make their software complaint with anticheat software so if you guys are willing to work with them on it that would be fantastic. We understand that you guys don't want to fully support linux but please meet us halfway and give us a way to make it work for ourselves.

Based on usage statistics elsewhere I figure around 1% of your playerbase is legitimate linux users playing via wine or qemu (a lot of the players that show up as xp in your metrics are probably wine users)

A lot of Linux users (including myself) posted in the anti-cheat thread when it was first announced and expressed our concerns. We were told that you all didn't intend to break Wine but wouldn't deal with it if it did. Since then, PBE has been broken completely for both VM and Wine users. I often play casually while breaking from working on prrogramming projects and constantly rebooting into Windows where programming is harder and inefficient just isn't an option. If QEMU wasn't broken too, I could alt-tab to the VM and it wouldn't be too bad but somehow virtual machines aren't allowed either. These are some incredibly broad anti-cheat rules that just don't seem fair to a small but incredibly dedicated fan base. Those of us who play on Linux had to work harder to get our games running. For me, it was completely worth it until now because League actually runs faster 
for me on Linux, despite running through Wine due to the optimized network and graphics stacks. I just wish there was a way for us to declare that we are using Wine and then have your anti-cheat system confirm that and run different checks. We are customers too that enjoy your product and we just want to keep playing.
As a Linux only user I'm really disappointed by the decision to break Wine compatibility. I've had a lot of fun playing league over the years, and I'm sorry it ends this way.

I will be asking something on behalf of Custom Skin community.

I'll preface this by saying that these changes will not stop what you call "skin porting", or basically making players use paid Riot skins instead of the base skin, for free. The custom skins isn't about that though. The custom skin community I am talking about is about creations, bringing back old textures and visuals, making new content. The modding and custom skin community is in my eyes an important part of the spaces where players can express and develop their creativity and love for the game.

Ever since the change of the champion's skin format to the "WAD" system, we have had to break the rules. The game checks the WAD files when it starts up a game, and if Riot's signature isn't on them, it will simply close and say an error happened, then it will repair your game. Therefore, we came up with a way to patch the game's exe so that it doesn't check for the WAD signature, lettins us use custom WAD and re-enable custom skins. This is fine except it's already against the rules to do anything on the .exe. We don't want to break the rules, but it was the only way for custom skins to continue existing.

With the encryption changes, we most likely will not be able to patch the .exe in that fashion, and even if we figure out a new way to do, players who do it might get flagged for cheating and receive punishments for essentially no reasons (as customs skins were always "use at your own risk but we tolerate it").

On behalf of the custom skin community, I seriously want a dialogue to be opened between us, creators, and Riot. We just want to be able to exist while staying in compliance in the rules. I think it is about time that actual discussion is started between us and Riot so that players can still have fun and express themselves in the space of modding and custom skins.

We already have started thinking about some solutions, and some changes are quite easy and costless to implement while not harming any of the security / anti cheat purposes that you are seeking.



In hope for an answer,

Sincerely yours, Charles "Hi I am me", EUW

Hey Charles, Thanks for sharing your feedback and thoughts. While I am not the owner of this decision I certainly can help open up a dialogue with the right people at Riot. I'll reach out to you directly with my contact information and we can start talking. Hopefully we can find a solution that works for the custom skin community and Riot. 

Just to add some context here it was not our goal to destroy the custom skin community when we moved to WAD files or now with our new anti-cheat protection system. I did not work on the WAD change but it was done for two main reasons: decreasing patch sizes (smaller, more succinct file format) and increasing stability when dealing with asset corruption. With the protection system we wanted to move beyond just detecting and banning. We want to keep as many cheats as possible out of the game. The war of cheating will always be an arms race but it is one we are committed to.

Why is riot actively blocking Virtual Machines?
i don't see how it would help much with scripting or boting since those people will just run in it on local installs now or bypass the anti-cheat detection. 
It only serves to screw over legit users who use Virtual Machines to increase security or do it for GPU-passthrough?
Virtual Machines are by all rights legit window PCs (which riot claims to support).
Its essentially like saying that asus or acer laptops are not allowed to run the game, like some kind of PC racism. :(

Why would you play on a VM anyway? 

What "security" difference will it make? A VM is still connected to your main pc, if your main PC had a virus in it, the person who made the virus would still be able to access your pw's (ofc not for all sites) through a complicated type of sniffing or man in the middle attack.

I'm sorry, but this claim is pretty stupid. The only times VM's really do increase security, is when you're reverse engineering/testing a virus (or doing a review of one). And when that's the case, the VM is fully encapsulated to itself (meaning no internet connection).  

Depending on what Riot does with the change, this will prevent a wide spread of level up bots. This will prevent a lot of scripting platforms and this will make the integrity of the game better. They will obviously monitor it and tweak based on what people prefer. But as it stands, the only people I've seen use a VM is for bot farms.

The only legit VM type thing I can think of for League is emulating Windows on a Mac because the Mac client always has so many problems.

The thing about VM's is it can prevent Riot from obtaining correct some types of unique Machine ID data to track cheaters/scripters and enforce bans. I used to volunteer on an old game that had that issue when Mac users were using Wine. Their Machine ID number was always just "1" which made it more difficult to track cheaters over multiple accounts. There are definately other ways, but it might heavily complicate things if Riot is trying to do so with an automated system.

There are also a reasonable number of Linux users that are now locked out (Mac is basically a modified closed source Linux). 

Indeed, using a VM increases your security. Software within a VM has no real access to your main operating system unless you give the rights. You basically run a VM to avoid getting a virus on your main operating system, test software, run software multiple times & a few more use cases. There are also people out there who are not allowed to run their private software outside a VM on their work laptop (nobody carries 2 laptops during a business trip [that applies to me :3 ] ). More and more technology companies are actually prescribing VM's. Today's computers hardly notice it anymore anyway. 

In the end it's a desperate attempt by Riot Games (sorry, but I look at it kinda realistically as programmer). Their game will have the bots & scripters probably for ever. It's a cat and mouse game. 2 botting platforms and many random dudes have already cracked the AntiCheat because it has been on the PBE for a while. The same will happen with the scripting platforms. Riot cannot infect/hook/control 100% of the windows system, so they have no chance of catching good cheaters. Microsoft cannot even protect its operating system from cracks. Valve has introduced VACnet some time ago - artificial Ai to catch the cheaters - the game is still full of cheaters. Only super obvious stuff gets caught. But at least their trust system sorts the suspicious players into their own games. Maybe Riot should try this path.

That just reflects my opinion! I could be wrong with some stuff, but from my research this is pretty much all true. Riot's new AntiCheat is btw called "packman" and they even suggest in the cracked lines of their code that you should check their careers page - WHAT? O.o 
I will not post links to different forum posts, but they are relatively easy to find and look very legit.

AntiCheats and DRM's have never really helped in big games 
(well... online multiplayer is the best "DRM" + first days sales).
But they often do things that are especially questionable for European laws (scan files, hook system, transfer files to their servers & probably more stuff I don't know about). Riot really should introduce a trust system like Valve did. I never have cheaters in my games on older accounts.
On the other hand, it probably costs a lot of money to run servers for bots & scripters.

> There are a lot of legitimate applications out there that we know you love, and we can’t test them all. **_We’ll need your help to identify the software that’s incompatible._**

While the idea to implement anti-cheat features is noble, this statement just doesn't sit right with me. If the solution isn't scalable and/or dynamic, it's gonna have huge issues when introduced to the myriads of different configurations that are used to run League.

What happens when new software is released that isn't compatible with the anti-cheat features? Will you have to write up a patch or two each and every time that new software is released to ensure it's anti-cheat compliant? To me, that doesn't seem feasible nor robust.

Being one of those minority LInux users since my introduction to League around 5 years ago, I've gone through a lot of the update changes and having to fix them in Wine time and time again. This wasn't a problem to me or others, as we could always find a way to work around the issues on the client side. However, when it gets to the point where we can't fix the issue on our side, then it feels like we're out of options.

My friends joke about how I should just dual-boot Windows to play all the games with them, but I'm firm about not supporting Windows because I think it's a terrible OS (my opinion).

I've held out for a Linux client for so long, but Riot doesn't want to support a Linux client with a small player base. I can't really blame them for that, it's a business and they don't really have any stake in Linux.

I hope this isn't how it ends guys, but it feels like it very well may be.
